name: Citronella plant
notes: drought tolerant. also known as mosquito plant. it is a geranium with a lemon scent, but does not actually repel mosquitoes.

name: Rosemary
notes: can handle temp being 0, but not sustained

name: Lavender
notes: check the variety of lavender, as some can't tolerate temps below 40, while others can handle 10 to -20

name: Italian Oregano
notes: allow soil to dry out between waterings

name: Greek Oregano
notes: allow soil to dry out between waterings

name: Lemon Thyme
notes: Perennial in zones 7 to 9, plant spacing 18 to 24 inches apart. Extremely tolerant of poor soil and drought conditions.

name: Romaine Lettuce
notes: cold weather plant

name: Boxwood
notes: Also named Buxus, Green Velvet, height 24-36 inches, space 36 inches

name: Miss Kim Lilac
notes: Also named syringa patula, Miss Kim, height 3-5 feet, space 5 feet, blooms early spring to summer

name: Flat Leaf Parsley
notes: Space 12 to 20 inches apart, depending on type, plant size 1 foot tall

name: Arugula (Roquette)
notes: Cool season plant. Leafy plants grow 6 to 12 inches tall while in the harvest stage. Once they bolt in late spring or early summer, the bloom stalks may grow 24 to 36 inches with (edible!) tan-white flowers on top, which signals that it is time to make room for warm-weather crops. However, some gardeners continue to harvest the leaves even from the tall plants, liking the stronger taste. You can even cut them back and pick some more until you finally tire of that and then pull them up and wait until fall to plant again.

name: Greek Basil
notes: A dwarf basil that grows into a rounded dome. Leaves are 1/2'" long and have a delicious sweet, spicy flavor. Perfect for decorative 3" to 6" pots. A tender annual that prefers sunny locations with rich soil. For best results, start indoors under lights and transplant outdoors after all danger of frost has passed. Pinch off flowers as soon as they appear to extend harvest. This variety is an excellent basil to grow indoors with sufficient light. 5-10 days to germination. 65-70 soil temperature. Full sun light requirements. 1/4th inch planting depth. Plant spacing 4 to 8 inches.

name: Sweet Potato Vine
notes: For containers, plant in a high quality all-purpose potting soil.

name: Artillery plant
notes: Propagation Methods: By dividing the rootball, From herbaceous stem cuttings

name: Chinese Money plant
notes: When overwatered, the Pilea's leaves will develop brown spotting and edging, and the leaves will begin to fall off the plant. If your plant is showing these symptoms, feel the soil. If it’s moist then hold off on watering until the soil dries all the way through the pot. Reference the care instructions for re-establishing a watering routine with your plant. Other causes for brown spotting are too much fertilizer, too much sun, or pests.

name: Pothos
notes: Bright indirect light is ideal, but plants are tolerant of low light and fluorescent lighting. Avoid direct sunlight, which can burn or discolor foliage.

name: Fiddleleaf fig plant
soilContent: Any good fast-draining potting soil will likely do
notes: in the wild thrive in warm and wet conditions

name: Red Aglaonema
soilContent: A well-drained lightly acidic potting soil
notes: mist

name: Pincushion peperomia
notes: Use a potting mix prepared with two parts peat and one part perlite or sand for best results.

name: Sensitive plant
notes: allow to dry and wilt a little but watch closely. do not overwater. yellow leaves appear when overwatered. mostly died. we'll see what happens.

name: Stapelia
notes: water once every 3-4 weeks in the winter, once every other week in the growing season. watch for mealy bugs, though they tend to appear from overwatering

name: Janet Craig Compacta (with stalk)
notes: tall one with stalk. yellow leaf, too little water or too much sunlight. Also brown leaf tips can mean needs to water with distilled. died when transferred from water only

name: Sansevieria
notes: slow growing. make sure soil is completely dry before watering again. water every 2-8 weeks, less often in winter.

name: Rabbit's Foot Fern
notes: water when top inch of soil is dry. Shallow pots work well for growing this houseplant. Make sure to change the pot every few years. Rabbit’s foot ferns need repotting about every two years, and the best time to repot is in spring. Mix regular potting soil half-and-half with sand to create an ideal medium for rabbit’s foot ferns. This is an excellent time to divide large plants.

name: Purple Waffle Plant
notes: low growing. died, didn't keep it moist enough

name: Corn Plant
notes: Soil shouldn't be allowed to dry out completely. Does not like direct sunlight. Does prefer some humidity. Repot every two or three years. Avoid using soil mixes that contain a large amount of perlite or fertilizers containing superphosphate with these plants. That's because Dracaenas are very sensitive to fluoride, which perlite and superphosphate contain. Can water with distilled water. In terms of lighting, the ideal location for this plant indoors is near a window with filtered sunlight. Too little light will result in the leaves losing their stripes, and it can cause the plant's growth to become stunted. But direct sun can burn the plant and cause it to wilt. Outdoors, the plant does best in part shade.

name: Boston Fern
soilContent: loamy rich organic mixture as a potting soil peat moss
notes: Don't like soggy soil. Mist frequently.

name: Jade
notes: young plants need bright, indirect sunlight, older need direct sunlight for 4 hours. water when mostly dried out, less in winter.

name: ZZ Plant
notes: young plants need bright, indirect sunlight, older need direct sunlight for 4 hours. water when mostly dried out, less in winter.

name: Bird's Nest Snake Plant
notes: These are small and slow growing so they can be grown in terrariums and dish gardens. Propagation can be done by dividing the rootball, from offsets and from leaf cuttings.

name: African milk tree plant
notes: Also known as Rubra or Royal Red. Can water once a week. Drought tolerant. Can grow up to 2 feet a year.

name: Fluffy Ruffle Fern
soilContent: garden soil, sand, peat moss or spaghnum
notes: Hybrid of a boston fern. Thrives in humidity. Mist frequently. Don't like soggy soil had fungus gnats. Put outside, got cold and it died.

name: Mini fan plant
notes: Not sure what the plant is named. Found in mini plant section at Gethsemane. Check frequently and do not allow to get completely dry or leaves will die. Update: died in December

name: Mini bushy plant
notes: Not sure what the plant is named. Found in Mariano's. water.

name: Mini flower succulent
notes: Not sure what the plant is named. Found in Trader Joe's. Very tall right now, need to be repotted.

name: Peacock plant
notes: evenly moist but not wet. if leaves are turning brown, more humidity. Update In January 2020, all the leaves curled up. Had to cut off two of the dying stems. Seems to curl up under the constant medium light on the plant shelf, probably dry there as well. Have it currently in the dining room. Changing Water from moist to moderate. After being in the dining room for a week and a half, leaves uncurled. No new leaves yet. April 2021, new leaves have been cropping up.

name: Asparagus fern
notes: drought tolerant. current one is a baby succulent.

name: Peace lily
soilContent: Peat-based potting mix with perlite sand or bark
notes: Drought tolerant. Wait until it droops a little to water. When your plant’s roots show or your peace lily seems to be drinking up all its water within a few days, re-pot into a larger container. Your plant may need to be gradually moved into larger and larger containers, but generally peace lilies won’t need to go into a pot larger than 10 inches.

name: Gerbera
notes: Keep watch. Gerbera daisies require full sun to partial shade, but they do not like intense heat. That said, allow for morning sun in warmer zones and full sun in cooler climates. Try not to plant Gerbera near a foundation or stone wall that will reflect heat back onto the plant.

name: Janet Craig Compacta (small)
notes: smaller version. keep an eye on it. use distilled water if the edge turn brown.

name: Pothos
notes: Bright indirect light is ideal, but plants are tolerant of low light and fluorescent lighting. Avoid direct sunlight, which can burn or discolor foliage.

name: Haworthia magnifica
notes: Can get up to 16 inches, but usually 3-5. Can form flowers. Keep dry. Look out for sunburned spots.

name: Flaming katy
notes: Can propagate with leaf cuttings. Will flower again with bright enough light.

name: Emerald Jade Carpet
notes: Can get up to 12 inches tall. Crassula may not be the right type of

name: Black Hens and Chicks
notes: This should be potted in full sunlight. Gets very tall and leggy in low light.

name: Buttercrunch lettuce
soilContent: moist but well-drained, nutrient-rich soil. Amend soil with compost, blood meal or other organic matter prior to planting. Fertile soil helps fuel fast, tender leaf development.
notes: when it gets hot outside, look to move buttercrunch lettuce into a cooler spot or it will wilt and bolt faster. keep moderate to moist

name: Bear's paw
soilContent: Well draining soil for succulents. Perlite or coarse sand can be added to ordinary potting soil.

name: Queen Victoria Agave
soilContent: Provide lean to average, well-drained soil.
notes: Provide lean to average, well-drained soil. Thrives in full sun in cool coastal areas; shelter from harsh afternoon sun and reflected heat in hot summer areas. Drought tolerant once established, but looks best with periodic water in extreme heat. The mother plant declines after flowering; younger rosettes will perpetuate the plant.

name: Spinach (Bloomsdale) (Seeds)
notes: USDA Organic (Back to the Roots). 1/2th inch planting depth. 6 inches spacing. 7-14 days to germination. 40-48 days to harvest. Cold weather crop.

name: Arugula (Roquette) (Seeds)
notes: Cool season plant. Leafy plants grow 6 to 12 inches tall while in the harvest stage. Once they bolt in late spring or early summer, the bloom stalks may grow 24 to 36 inches with (edible!) tan-white flowers on top, which signals that it is time to make room for warm-weather crops. However, some gardeners continue to harvest the leaves even from the tall plants, liking the stronger taste. You can even cut them back and pick some more until you finally tire of that and then pull them up and wait until fall to plant again. 1/8th planting depth. 6 inches spacing. 5-7 days to germination. 40 days to harvest. Plant seeds outdoors in dense 2-4 inch bands for baby greens, or 6 inches apart for full-sized plants.

name: Mesclun (Spicy Mix)
notes: Full sun 6 or more hours. 21-35 days to harvest. Depth 1/4 inches. Thin 12 inches. Container friendly. Includes 20 percent lettuces Red Salad Bowl', 20 percent mustard Mizuna, 20 percent endive Green Curled, 20 percent radicchio Red Treviso and 20 percent arugula Rocket. Sow in average soil in full sun in early spring, again in late summer for fall crop. Sow thinly in rows 12 inches apart and cover with 1/4th inch of fine soil. Firm lightly and keep evenly moist. Seedlings emerge in 10-14 days.

name: Lemon Balm
notes: Lemon balm grows best in cool weather. In freezing temperatures, it will die back to the ground then regrow from the roots in spring. Plant form and size: Lemon balm grows to 12 to 24 inches tall and wide; it grows in clumps of branched stems with loose terminal clusters of small white to creamy yellow flowers at the top. Lemon balm may be mistaken for mint at first glance. Flowers: Small white flowers are borne in tight clusters at the axles along the length of the stems. Bloom time: Lemon balm blooms throughout the summer and into fall. Leaves: Lemon balm has lemon-scented, oval, toothed leaves that are heavily veined or quilted from 2 to 3 inches long arranged opposite one another on four-sided stems. Leave are coarsely toothed with a bristly surface.

name: Maidenhair Fern
notes: A graceful, delicate-looking fern, beautiful in rock gardens, shaded gardens, and woodland settings. Complements wild ginger, pulmonaria, hellebore, and hosta as well as spring-flowering bulbs. The fronds can be used as filler in bouquets. Easily grown in average, medium, well-drained soil in part shade to full shade. Prefers moist, humusy, acidic soils in full shade. Spreads slowly by creeping, branching rhizomes to form large colonies over time.
